1. Definition of a Group

A group is a pair (G,âˆ˜) consisting of a set G and an operation âˆ˜ that satisfies four axioms.

Group Axioms

  1. Closure: $\forall a,b \in G: a \circ b \in G$
  2. Associativity: $\forall a,b,c \in G: (a \circ b) \circ c = a \circ (b \circ c)$
  3. Identity Element: $\exists e \in G \forall a \in G: e \circ a = a \circ e = a$
  4. Inverse Elements: $\forall a \in G \exists a^{-1} \in G: a \circ a^{-1} = a^{-1} \circ a = e$

2. Important Examples

Number Groups

  • $\mathbb{Z}$ with addition
  • $\mathbb{Q}\setminus\{0\}$ with multiplication
  • $\mathbb{R}\setminus\{0\}$ with multiplication
  • $\mathbb{C}\setminus\{0\}$ with multiplication

Symmetric Group

$S_n$: set of all permutations of n elements

$$|S_n| = n!$$

Matrix Groups

  • $GL_n(\mathbb{R})$: invertible $n \times n$ matrices
  • $SL_n(\mathbb{R})$: matrices with determinant 1
  • $O_n(\mathbb{R})$: orthogonal matrices

3. Fundamental Properties

Uniqueness of the Identity Element

The identity element e is uniquely determined.

Uniqueness of Inverses

For each element a, there exists exactly one inverse element $a^{-1}$.

Cancellation Laws

$$\forall a,b,c \in G: a \circ b = a \circ c \Rightarrow b = c$$

$$\forall a,b,c \in G: b \circ a = c \circ a \Rightarrow b = c$$

Subgroup Criterion

H âŠ† G is a subgroup if and only if:

$$\forall a,b \in H: a \circ b^{-1} \in H$$

5. Homomorphisms

Group Homomorphism

A mapping $f: G \to H$ between groups is called a homomorphism if:

$$\forall a,b \in G: f(a \circ_G b) = f(a) \circ_H f(b)$$

Special Cases

  • Monomorphism: injective homomorphism
  • Epimorphism: surjective homomorphism
  • Isomorphism: bijective homomorphism

6. Applications

Symmetries

  • Description of symmetries of geometric objects
  • Crystal structures in chemistry
  • Symmetries in quantum mechanics

Cryptography

  • RSA encryption
  • Elliptic curves
  • Digital signatures
